entities.name: MARCEL PROUST
entities.description: French author known for his work on the Proustian effect, where the smell of a madeleine cookie triggered a flood of childhood memories

entities.name: AROMATHERAPY
entities.description: A form of alternative medicine that uses plant-derived essential oils to improve physical and psychological well-being

entities.name: ALZHEIMER'S DISEASE
entities.description: A progressive neurological disorder that affects memory, thinking, and behavior, often treated with methods that include exposure to familiar scents

entities.name: POST-TRAUMATIC STRESS DISORDER (PTSD)
entities.description: A mental health condition triggered by a terrifying event, either experiencing it or witnessing it, often treated with methods that include exposure to familiar scents

entities.name: THE FRAGRANCE INDUSTRY
entities.description: A multi-billion-dollar business that designs and sells perfumes and colognes to evoke specific emotions and create lasting impressions

entities.name: HUMAN BODY
entities.description: The biological system of a human, which includes the olfactory system responsible for the sense of smell

entities.name: ODOR MOLECULES
entities.description: Molecules that enter the nasal cavity and bind to olfactory receptors, triggering the sense of smell

entities.name: OLFACTORY RECEPTORS
entities.description: Specialized cells in the olfactory epithelium that detect odor molecules and send signals to the brain

entities.name: OLFACTORY EPITHELIUM
entities.description: A thin layer of tissue in the nasal cavity where olfactory receptors are located

entities.name: BRAIN
entities.description: The central organ of the nervous system, which processes and interprets signals from the olfactory receptors

entities.name: EARLY HUMANS
entities.description: Ancestors of modern humans who relied heavily on their sense of smell for survival

entities.name: PREDATORS
entities.description: Animals that hunt other animals for food, which early humans needed to detect using their sense of smell

entities.name: FOOD
entities.description: Substances consumed by organisms for nutritional support, which early humans found using their sense of smell

entities.name: LIMBIC SYSTEM
entities.description: A complex set of brain structures that play a role in emotions, memories, and the olfactory system

entities.name: MADELEINE COOKIE
entities.description: A small, shell-shaped cake that triggered Marcel Proust's vivid childhood memories

entities.name: LAVENDER
entities.description: A plant-derived essential oil used in aromatherapy for its relaxing properties

entities.name: PEPPERMINT
entities.description: A plant-derived essential oil used in aromatherapy for its focus-enhancing properties

entities.name: INCENSE
entities.description: A fragrant biotic material that is burned to release a pleasant aroma, often used in cultural practices

entities.name: SPICES
entities.description: A variety of dried seeds, fruits, roots, barks, or other plant substances used for flavoring, coloring, or preserving food, often valued for their scents

entities.name: FLORAL FRAGRANCES
entities.description: Scents derived from flowers, often used in perfumes and colognes

entities.name: CITRUS FRAGRANCES
entities.description: Scents derived from citrus fruits, often used in perfumes and colognes

entities.name: PERFUMES
entities.description: Fragrant substances used to create a pleasant scent, often worn for personal or social reasons

entities.name: COLOGNES
entities.description: Fragrant substances used to create a pleasant scent, often worn for personal or social reasons

relations: Marcel Proust's work on the Proustian effect highlights the emotional and memory-evoking power of scents, which is a principle used in aromatherapy
The smell of a madeleine cookie triggered Marcel Proust's vivid childhood memories, illustrating the Proustian effect
Aromatherapy is used as a treatment to help people with Alzheimer's disease recall memories and reduce anxiety
Aromatherapy is used as a treatment to help people with PTSD recall memories and reduce anxiety
The fragrance industry leverages the principles of aromatherapy to create scents that evoke specific emotions and create lasting impressions
Aromatherapy uses lavender for its relaxing properties
Aromatherapy uses peppermint for its focus-enhancing properties
The fragrance industry values incense for its pleasant aroma and cultural significance
The fragrance industry values spices for their unique scents and cultural significance
The fragrance industry uses floral fragrances to create pleasant and appealing scents
The fragrance industry uses citrus fragrances to create fresh and invigorating scents
The fragrance industry designs and sells perfumes to evoke specific emotions and create lasting impressions
The fragrance industry designs and sells colognes to evoke specific emotions and create lasting impressions
The science of smell explores the mechanisms of the olfactory system within the human body
The science of smell studies how odor molecules interact with the olfactory system
The science of smell examines the role of olfactory receptors in detecting smells
The science of smell investigates the structure and function of the olfactory epithelium
The science of smell explores how the brain processes and interprets olfactory signals
The limbic system is a part of the brain that processes emotions and memories, closely linked to the olfactory system
Early humans used their sense of smell to detect predators, a key survival mechanism
Early humans used their sense of smell to find food, a crucial aspect of survival
Early humans used their sense of smell to identify potential mates, aiding in reproduction
